Package de.fu.weave Description

Weave is a tiny web-framework for Java which is developed along with Scetris myCourses during the SCORE Contest 2011.

Weave is built around the Java Servlet API and thus runs without any other dependencies in any Servlet Container, such as Tomcat or Jetty. The general idea is, that a Servlet (called Weavlet) is acting as a controller which delegates requests to Modules, which contain the actual business logic. Weave is designed to be as generic as possible, i.e. things are abstracted as much as possible.

Design

While the current implementation is focused on Java servlets, the design is intended to abstract from the fact that the application is running as a web-application. In theory it is perfectly possible to imagine a weave application to be run as a CLI (command line interface) or GUI (graphical user interface) application. A Weave application is split into Modules which are further separated into Actions. Actions are basically functions and should not have any side effects. Modules are required to return an XML-Document (typically represented by Document) which is than processed by the Controller. A controller which is a servlet is called a Weavlet.

Weave applications are primarily applications dealing with a database. Thus every component has access to a RelationManager, which is unique to every application.

Weavlet

A Weavlet is a Weave-Controller implemented as a Servlet. It features

Forms

A major issue in decoupling business logic and controlling logic is how to deal with user data. Thus, forms are represented as Java classes. The real forms are created by a form-builder to target the desired output medium (GUI, CLI, PDF, XHTML, XForms, ...). See Form.

Future thoughts

In principle it does not matter whether modules are running inside a Weavlet or somewhere else. A Weave-Controller could possibly be implemented using Swing, thus turning a web application into a gui application. Of course, the form-builder (which is realised via XSL-T in the current implementation de.fu.weave.impl.frigg) will have to be newly created.

Contents

This package contains interfaces, definitions and default implementations (such as Session).
